Navigational tools for desktop virtual environment interfaces

Navigational tools for desktop virtual environment interfaces

  • H. M. Sayers1,
  • S. Wilson1 &
  • M. D. J. McNeill1 

Virtual Reality volume 7, pages131–139(2004)Cite this article

  • 142 Accesses

  • 8 Citations

  • 0 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Desktop systems typically rely on a two-dimensional (2D) software interface and general purpose hardware (mouse, keyboard) for interaction with a three-dimensional (3D) virtual environment. These interfaces must provide all the functionality required to navigate through and interact with the virtual environment, yet research into the usability aspects of the tools presented on these software interfaces indicates that the majority of users experience some degree of frustration when using them to perform even relatively simple tasks. This paper begins with a study of usability issues for interfaces to virtual environments on desktop systems, and details a series of experiments performed to evaluate the usability of a number of navigational tools. Participants were tested on the time taken to complete a number of navigational tasks with a series of interfaces presenting different navigational tools. The tools presented were a speed control function, a you-are-here (YAH) map, a function enabling the user to mark and teleport to any location within the presented environment, and an undo function. Results indicate that the visual presentation of navigational aids improves navigation performance, in terms of the time taken to complete tasks, and also improves user satisfaction with the desktop system.

Introduction

A three-dimensional (3D) virtual environment (VE) is a computer representation of a real world space or an imaginary world through which users can navigate. Many VE applications also offer users the ability to interact with objects in the environment, by moving objects, perhaps, or by causing some event to happen, such as pressing a switch to turn on a light. Applications which use VEs can be broadly classified into those requiring fully immersive solutions and those which do not. Fully immersive systems are characterised by the use of head-mounted displays, sometimes augmented by hand and other limb motion tracking devices, or more recently by the use of specially fabricated rooms, where three, four or five walls are display devices (Hand 1997). Desktop systems, on the other hand, exploit off-the-shelf equipment (such as personal computers) and although obviously offer a much less reduced sense of presence in the VE are still useful for many application areas (Green and Jacob 1991).

Although many proprietary standards exist for defining VEs, a common industry standard is the Virtual Reality Modeling Language (VRML), International Standard ISO/IEC 14772–1:1997. Since all popular Internet browsers support VRML, VE technology has been opened up to a wide range of users using standard desktop systems, an Internet browser, and a mouse and keyboard for interaction.

Interfaces to virtual environments on desktop systems

Research has shown that VE interfaces pose new challenges to human-computer interface design (Kaur et al. 1998). Characteristics identified as particular to VE user interfaces include the need for continuous response and feedback in real time and support for various types of movement for navigation and interaction tasks (Green and Jacob 1991). Existing user interface guidelines do not address the particular requirements for interfaces to VEs: no standard “look and feel” has yet evolved for user interfaces to 3D worlds (Hand 1997).

Usability, a key concept in the field of human-computer interaction, is concerned with making systems easy to learn and easy to use. Good usability is important to ensure the acceptability of systems and reduce the frustration of users (Preece et al. 1994). Users of VE applications, like all computer users, require intuitive tools to maximise their productivity. In VE applications this normally means effective navigation and interaction. Although there has been much research on designing virtual environments for usability (Fencott 1999; Kaur 1998; Kaur Deol et al. 1999; Sayers et al. 1999), there has been little consideration so far of the usability of the tools (enabling effective navigation and interaction) presented on interfaces to VEs on desktop systems. In the next section of this paper we identify usability criteria, namely navigation issues, for interfaces to virtual environments for desktop systems, and in particular the findings from our previous usability evaluations of current interfaces. The next section presents the design of a novel interface resulting from these usability studies along with a description of the experiments performed, while the next section presents the results and experimental findings. Finally, conclusions and plans for further work are discussed.

Usability issues

Usability concerns how easy a system is for the user to understand and use and how efficient that system is (Kaur 1998). Usability measures how well users can carry out their tasks or meet goals when using an application and therefore affects its overall success (Nielsen 1993). The particular notion of a user-centered design approach to VE interfaces is not as straightforward as for traditional computing applications. The particular concepts and technologies associated with VEs mean that their interfaces are more difficult to design, implement and use than conventional interfaces (Herndon et al. 1994). The third dimension brings with it issues such as user position within the environment, human-like navigation, viewpoint control and the exploratory nature of interaction. Informing the user of what can be interacted with and what can be achieved within the environment is one of the major design challenges for VE interfaces.

VE application users have varying objectives depending on the context. Users of 3D games, for instance, will have different requirements from users of a multi-dimensional information visualisation space or users interacting with others in a collaborative virtual engineering application. The key tasks of navigation and interaction, however, are common to users of all VE applications. Navigation is the process of moving around an environment, deciding at each step where to go (Jul and Furnas 1997). It has been identified as the default behaviour which VE users return to, for example, after carrying out the manipulation of an object within an environment (Kaur 1998). Significant usability problems in VEs, however, have been found to be caused by navigation problems (Darken et al. 1998). As a result a large body of work exists which focuses on various issues related to 3D navigation including several studies investigating the differences in spatial knowledge acquired from maps and exploration (Thorndyke and Hayes-Roth 1982; Ruddle et al. 1999; Waller et al. 1998; Witmer et al. 1996). The usefulness of landmarks in supporting navigation in large virtual worlds has also been emphasised (Vinson 1999; Darken and Sibert 1996). Other studies have investigated the use of more novel navigation aids such as the worlds in miniature (WIM) metaphor (Stoackley et al. 1995). This metaphor provides the user with a miniature representation of the environment held in a virtual hand and superimposed over a section of the environment itself. Both the WIM and the environment can be directly manipulated. Elvins et al. (1998) use a similar approach except that their worldlets technique does not involve an overlap with the environment being presented. The worldlets are 3D interactive thumbnails displayed outside the environment, which can be explored and manipulated in a similar way. Chittaro and Scagnetto (2001) concluded that semitransparency, where users are able to see through occluded surfaces within the VE, is a useful navigational aid.

Typical navigation problems include users becoming “lost” in virtual worlds (disorientation), users making perceptual misjudgements due to inadequate visual displays (Rushton and Wann 1993), and confusion caused when interactions do not produce the expected result. The problem of user disorientation has been attributed to a number of factors, including:

  • lack of support for control of velocity (Rushton and Wann 1993; Mohageg et al. 1996). Getting lost or becoming disoriented in an environment frequently occurs when the speed of movement is too fast (Miller 1994) and while faster speeds may reduce time and effort in movement over large distances, slower speeds have been found to be better in carrying out precise movements (Johnsgard 1994). Navigation speed, therefore, needs to be appropriate for the size of the scene and the tasks which have to be carried out.

  • problems relating to navigational “modes”, for example “walking” and “flying” (Johnsgard 1994; Tan et al. 2001). Even when in walk mode, users can become disoriented if movement is not confined to a level plane (Sayers et al. 2000).

  • problems when navigating too close to (Kaur et al. 1998; Marsh and Wright 1999) or through virtual world objects (Marsh et al. 2000).

  • problems related to the cognitive load placed on the navigator (Smith et al. 1999).

  • problems caused by the restricted field of view available on the screen (Neale 1997).

  • lack of identifiable landmarks (cues) in the VE (Darken and Sibert 1996).

  • support for automatic navigation (“teleporting”) to predefined locations (Mohageg et al. 1996). Although this has been found to be an effective means of moving to specific locations, it can increase the user’s sense of disorientation if further indicators of position within the environment, such as a map, are not provided (Sayers et al. 2000; Tan et al. 2001).

These problems have been shown to result in user frustration and consequently low usability (Kaur et al. 1996; Miller 1994). When a user encounters a VE for the first time, it may take some considerable time to gain enough familiarity with the environment to enable successful navigation to take place—time which users may not be willing to offer (Ruddle et al. 1997). The presentation of navigational aids on the VE interface is therefore a significant usability issue.

Evaluating usability

The implementation of interaction and navigation techniques in VE applications is often fraught with technical difficulties which have meant that evaluating their usability has received less attention than it should (Hand 1997). Earlier experimental findings on the navigational usability of existing 3D browser interfaces identified a number of usability issues (Sayers et al. 2000). These included:

Velocity— :

many users found the default speed within the browser application too fast. The tested interfaces which allowed for the manipulation of speed control did not have visual controls available on their toolbars for this purpose which resulted in users not realizing that this option was available to them or not being able to find the control easily. In fact, those who did find the control were dissatisfied with the level of control supplied, finding that the changes accommodated made very little difference.

Collisions / error correction— :

collisions with objects within the environment were frequent and rectifying the situation was found to be very difficult. Users often had to resort to teleporting to predefined locations, abandoning sequential navigation, which resulted in subsequent disorientation. Participants frequently wanted to be able to “undo” a particular movement, yet none of the interfaces assessed supported this feature.

Precise movements— :

navigation involving the performance of intricate movements, for example, moving around an object placed close to a wall, proved difficult. Both speed of movement and correcting collisions were factors in this problem.

The viewing plane— :

participants evidently preferred to move on a level plane as if walking in the real world and would have preferred to have their movement constrained in this way.

The overall effect of these usability issues was frustration and disorientation. Users were asked to make suggestions for improvements and these included some form of speed control visible to the user, an overview map to help when disoriented, an undo facility to delete incorrect actions quickly, and the ability to name locations in addition to being able to choose from a list of predefined locations.

The amount of time taken to complete the tasks for each interface corresponded to its subjective rating: the better rated subjectively, the faster the completion of the tasks. As a result of these findings a novel interface was designed to address the problems identified in the usability study and to enable a more thorough investigation of the usefulness of various navigational tools presented on interfaces to three-dimensional worlds on desktop systems.

The experimental interface

An application was developed to load VRML files with various navigational tools presented on the screen. The development was carried out using Java3D technology. The problems presented earlier were addressed by the provision of visible tools on the screen (Fig. 1).

A slider bar allows the user to adjust the speed of movement, with the default speed set to “walk”. A button labelled “Show Map” activates a you-are-here (YAH) map presented in the top left-hand corner of the screen marking the user’s current location within the environment (Fig. 2). A button labelled “Mark” allows the user to label any location within the environment. These user-defined locations are then listed above and by clicking on any location within the list, the user is teleported to that location (Fig. 3). A button labelled “Undo” allows users to undo their previous actions one by one. A dial showing the direction of movement (North, South, East and West) was also included on the interface since it emerged as a highly rated feature in the earlier evaluative analysis of current desktop 3D browsers (Sayers et al. 2000). This study also reinforced the need to display all necessary tools on the interface—participants were strongly of the opinion that there should be no hidden functionality.

The experiment design

A study was developed to test the effectiveness of the tools presented within this interface. The tools can be displayed individually, all together, or hidden from view completely through choices provided on the “View” menu on the top menubar—a total of six variations of the interface. The control condition had no tools presented on the screen. A timer with “Start”, “Stop”, “Reset” and “Hide” options is also available for display from the “Options” drop-down menu (Fig. 4) in order to eliminate the need for manual timing of tasks. 24 individuals (18 female, six male), aged between 19 and 53 and inexperienced in 3D navigation (notably computer games), volunteered as participants in this experiment, and were randomly split into six groups—one group for each test condition.

This between-groups division was necessary to eliminate the learning effects due to the acquisition of navigational knowledge and experience with the navigational tools. All groups were asked to carry out a navigation task in a VE.

The test VE used was an L-shaped “virtual corridor” developed in VRML. The test scene was kept as simple as possible with rooms differentiated by colour. Participants were positioned to start at the entrance to the corridor and then instructed to move into a set of six rooms consecutively within the environment in search of various objects and then finally back to the starting position. Once in a room, participants had to search for a variety of objects placed in various positions. The aim of this activity was to incorporate some precise movements within the navigation tasks. Large movements such as moving down the corridor were combined with more precise, intricate movements such as entering and leaving the rooms through the doorway, turning around and moving around and behind objects. Timed results were sent to a text file on their completion. Travel inside the environment was based on an egocentric, first-person perspective “walk” mode where the part of the environment which would be in front of the user’s own eyes was displayed and in which users controlled movement using the mouse. Collision detection was used to prevent users moving through objects or surfaces.

Participants were briefed at the beginning of the experiment on the functionality of whatever (if any) tools were presented on-screen and were allowed 15 minutes to practise navigating using the mouse along with the tools presented. Each individual was observed while navigating and was encouraged to use a “think-aloud” technique to record their subjective views. On completion, participants were asked to complete a usability questionnaire which consisted of a set of statements designed to measure, using a scale of 1–7 (strongly disagree to strongly agree), how easy it was to navigate, how comfortable they felt using the application and how satisfied they were with the navigational aids presented. The questionnaire also gave participants the opportunity to comment on the most negative or positive aspects of their experience and to suggest how it might be improved.

The experimental hypotheses and the procedure

Previous experimental results and observations led to the following two general hypotheses:

  1. 1.

    The groups provided with visible navigational aids would perform better and would be more satisfied with the interface than the control group. The motivation for this hypothesis was derived from the lack of an interface which provided a clearly usable range of visual tools, and the fact that participants using the interface which displayed no navigational tools in earlier experiments gave significantly lower usability ratings for the interface and even had to abandon the tasks in some cases.

  2. 2.

    The group presented with all the available navigational tools would perform better than the groups provided with only one navigational tool. This hypothesis is based on the assumption that different users find different navigational aids most useful—while some may become disoriented easily and find the map most useful, others may prefer to move more slowly to perform intricate movements.

A one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was performed. A between-subjects randomised design was used. We considered the availability of navigational aids as the independent variables for the study (no aids (control group), speed, map, mark, undo and all controls), while the dependent variable was the time required to complete the task.

Results and analysis

The results of the ANOVA (F(5,18)=3.08, p<0.05) indicated that there was a significant effect of the independent variable—the interface presented had a significant effect on the time taken to complete the navigation task. A trend analysis showed that there was a significant linear effect across the groups (F(1,18)=11.26, p<0.01), indicating that as each tool was tested, from the control condition through “speed”, “map”, “mark”, “undo” and “all controls”, the performance time improved proportionately. A chart showing mean times to complete the tasks is displayed in Fig. 5, and although a general linear trend can be identified, the map group had a larger mean than the control group. From observation, those using the “map” control accessed the tool very infrequently and in the post-study questionnaire indicated that they found that the relatively small environment along with the fact that they had specific navigational instructions meant that they didn’t need to use the tool. The results from the map group, therefore, should perhaps be combined with the control group results in this case in an attempt to explain the increase in mean time taken by this group of participants. Map group participants did, however, feel that a map would be particularly useful in a larger environment—a finding from previous studies on wayfinding with large-scale 3D scenes (Ruddle et al. 1999). There were many positive comments on the usefulness of both the “mark” function and the “undo” function within the usability questionnaire reflecting the better performance times of the participants in these groups. Collisions occurred with all participants, yet were more easily rectified when these functions were available. Using the “mark” function, participants were able to teleport out of a difficult situation to their most recently marked location and begin the task again. This feature freed them from the restrictions of pre-defined locations while still enabling them to build a cognitive map of the environment.

Further analysis to test if there was any significant difference between the performance of individual groups was required. To this end, a number of planned contrasts were designed to ascertain if there were differences between: the control group and the groups presenting tools; the group presenting all tools and those presenting only one; the group using the “undo” function and the other single tool groups; the group using the “mark” function and those using the “speed” and “show map” functions; and between the groups using the “map” and “speed” functions. The results for the first contrast, to test whether the inclusion of tools improved performance time, indicated that there was a significant improvement in performance (t(18)=-2.129, p<0.05). The second contrast also proved significant (t(18)=2.221, p<0.05) with the presentation of a number of tools improving performance when compared to the presentation of only one navigation aid. In the case of the final three contrasts, comparing the groups with individual tools, no significant difference was found (p>0.05), although the mean times for task completion were much better for the “mark” and “undo” groups (see Fig. 5).

Qualitative analysis

Results of subjective impressions collected by the post-study questionnaire are presented in Fig. 6. Subjects were presented with five statements relating to the ease of navigation, the tools presented on the interface and their satisfaction with the system. Subjective ratings from 1 to 7, based on Nielsen’s attributes of usability (Nielsen 1993), were used to represent “strongly disagree” through to “strongly agree”, respectively.

Considering observations made during the experiments themselves, the results from this questionnaire were sometimes surprising since there was often no correlation between what was observed and the ratings given. From observation, for example, it was obvious that participants in the control group experienced a high degree of frustration with the application, yet they did not reflect this in the usability questionnaire. Very few participants clearly indicated dissatisfaction with the application. This may be explained by factors such as the novelty of the 3D navigation, not understanding or having adequate knowledge about the statements presented, or “politeness” since they were being observed. Other factors which could have a bearing on this finding include the small environment used for the evaluation. Further studies are planned based on several VEs of different sizes and using larger user group sizes.

The group using the “map” tool (which had the highest mean time) indicated lower ratings than the other groups, and, as expected, the group with “all controls” rated the statements higher than the other groups. The comments written (and spoken) by participants in relation to the “mark” and “undo” tools were very encouraging and the statistical analysis of timed results shows clearly that they both enabled participants to complete the navigation task more quickly, yet these comments and results are not borne out by the subjective ratings given (see Fig. 6).

Observation of the experiments also revealed that several participants were confused by the cursor’s change of shape when the left mouse button was pressed to enable movement. Rather than relying on the first-person perspective, they imagined that the position of the cursor on the screen was either the location they were currently in or the location they were moving towards. This is a factor which will need to be taken into consideration in further studies using the test interface.

It was also noticeable that no participants found the dial showing movement of direction either North, South, East or West (see Fig. 1)—a highly rated feature in the evaluation of existing applications—to be particularly useful. In fact, several participants commented that they didn’t use it at all.

Differences in gender were not considered in the analysis of results due to the uneven gender balance of participants. These initial experiments were carried out during the summer semester of the university when there are much fewer students and staff on campus, and since participants were required to have little or no previous 3D navigation experience, it was difficult to balance the number within the gender category.

Conclusions

One of the most relevant usability issues for desktop virtual environments is the navigational support provided by its user interface. Inadequate provision of support for user navigation leads to user disorientation and frustration. With the growing number of VEs on the World Wide Web, these problems become even more significant since frustrated users are more likely to abandon the site. VEs are also being increasingly used to present abstract information, broadening again the user community. This study has intentionally omitted competent 3D gamers from the evaluation, in an attempt to establish what this broadening user community requires in terms of navigational aids.

The experimental study presented in this paper has confirmed the hypothesised positive effects of the presence of visual navigational tools on user navigation performance in desktop VEs, and has also highlighted the fact that the presence of a number of visual tools improves navigation performance more significantly than any individual tool presented on its own.

This study did not strongly differentiate between the usefulness of individual navigational aids. Qualitative analysis, however, suggests that the provision of a visible “undo” facility or the ability to mark user-defined locations are particularly helpful aids in the navigation process. Further work involving much larger groups of participants needs to be carried out to investigate the effects of individual tools in more detail, as well as studies to determine the usefulness of the visual aids when navigating in much larger VEs. Future research is also planned to investigate the effect of gender on navigational performance using these visual aids.
